review.title: Compatible extensions and consistent closures: a fuzzy approach
review.abstract: In this paper $\ast$--compatible extensions of fuzzy relations are studied, generalizing some results obtained by Duggan in case of crisp relations. From this general result are obtained as particular cases fuzzy versions of some important extension theorems for crisp relations (Szpilrajn, Hansson, Suzumura). Two notions of consistent closure of a fuzzy relation are introduced.

sections.heading: 3 Preliminaries on t–norms and fuzzy relations
sections.text: In this section, some definitions and basic properties are defined on left-continuous t standards and blurred relationships: a = eternal-c = eternal. They are used in the next sections to define the formal context of the paper, and as a technical tool to prove the results.Let [0, 1] be the unit interval. sections.heading: 4 Compatible extensions revisited
sections.text: In this section, we will propose a more appropriate concept of compatible extension, the concept of compatible extension being given in the context of the fuzzy sets theory associated with a left-continuous t-norm and using the residual instead of negation. In the case of the go-del norm, one gets a stronger idea than in [13]. Two extension theories that generalize Duggan's result (Theorem 2.4) are proven, the first of which is formulated for a left-continuous t-norm and the second for the go-del-norm. Their evidence will use a series of preliminary lemmas and propositions based on -compatible extensions that have an intrinsic interest.

sections.heading: 5 Particular cases
sections.text: This section deals with some specific cases of Theorem 4.20. In this way, we will get some fuzzy versions of the classic Q extension theorems (Szpilrajn, Hansson, Suzumura). In this section, we will work with the Go-del-t norm-A. First, we will recall the definition of some classes of fuzzy relationships. Afuzzy relation R to X is referred to as: • fuzzy preorder if R is reflexive and transitive. We will • R1 = the class of fuzzy suborders on X; • R2 = the class of fuzzy preorders on X; • R3 = the class of fuzzy preorders on X -transitive suborders; • fuzzy strict partial order if R is irreflexive and в -transitive. Classes R1, R2, R3, R3 are closed and arc-rective.This dilemma shows that Theorem 4.20 can be applied to X -transitive relationships on R2.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusions
sections.text: This paper contains the following contributions: (a) A new idea of a compatible extension of a blurred relationship is defined, and on this basis a new kind of consistency of blurred relations is introduced. (b) These two terms differ from those of [13], against which they have the advantage of being defined only by the remainder associated with a left-continuous t-norm. (c) This general result results in blurred versions of some important extension theorems for blurred relations (Szpilrajn, Hansson and Suzumura). (c) The notion of a consistent conclusion of a blurred relationship [3] is generalized to blurred relations by two constructions: R-and R-shaped generalizations (R-shaped theorems). (D-shaped theory) generalizes to the type of consistency (Szpilrajn, Hansson and Suzumura).

referenceMentions.context: In his seminal paper [23] Szpilrajn proved an extension theorem of a strict partial order to a total strict order.
This result led afterwards to other extension theorems [3], [4], [11], [21].

The notion of consistency was introduced by Suzumura in [21] in order to weaken transitivity.
For the second type extensions, Duggan [10] uses the notion ”compatible extensions”.
Suzumura’s theorem [21] links the consistency with the compatible extensions: a relation is consistent iff it admits a total and transitive compatible extension.

In [10] Duggan establishes a very general result which encompasses the theorems of Szpilrajn [23], Hansson [17], Suzumura [21], Dushnik–Miller [11] and Donaldson–Weymark [9] and other new particular cases.

metadata.abstractText: In this paper ∗–compatible extensions of fuzzy relations are studied, generalizing some results obtained by Duggan in case of crisp relations. From this general result are obtained as particular cases fuzzy versions of some important extension theorems for crisp relations (Szpilrajn, Hansson, Suzumura). Two notions of consistent closure of a fuzzy relation are introduced.
